Don't Starve Together is a really great game, it's like Don't Starve all over again, but this time with friends!  You may think playing with friends is easier, but it makes everything so much harder! Firstly, you need more food to feed yourselves. Secondly, people may (sometimes) want to PvP, even in other servers, like what happened to me...I died because they saw that I was a noob and decided to kill me multiple times for fun. Thirdly (the worst), because you may be playing with friends, the monsters' health are increased drastically! EVEN if you are playing single player mode! This makes the game all the more difficult, and fun for you and your friends, and is also a great test of your teamwork, patience, and your friendships >:D  However, they decided to make other aspects of the game easier and more fun: -You can play ANY character, even Maxwell from the beginning! (Don't Starve needed you to unlock each character by earning enough EXP, which takes a TON of time) -There are new items and other stuff which are not available in DS -Multiplayer! (duh) More people means more challenges, and more challenges means more fun! (and raging) -Fun and challenging events such as The Forge, The Gorge, Year of the (Insert creature here) and lots more will keep you from getting bored and leave you with fresh challenges all-year-round!  This game can kill hours upon hours. As you play, the seasons will change, bringing you new challenges everytime, which may even kill inexperienced players (like me).However, with enough practice, you can surely master the game, and even go beyond just surviving, thriving! Just don't get cocky, even experienced players may screw up some time or another.  Lastly, purchasing this game will include another complementory copy, which can then be gifted to your friend, so they can play with you as well!  Overall, this game is REALLY worth the time and money, and can even keep you hooked for years!  Originality: 9/10 Challenges: 10/10 Multiplayer feature: 7/10 (There may be some errors or problems when joining other people's servers) Graphics: 10/10

I played this both a year ago and am playing it now. Some info for those considering picking it up. TLDR: Get it, it's great and damn cheap. Also lag issues most reviews mention are relics from last year and have been fixed.  I've been playing Don't Starve Together with my best friend in the US (I'm in AUS) for a few weeks now. We had played it about a year ago for a week or two as well.   1.) Content seems to encompass all of the vanilla game + the vast majority of RoG expansion, but does not include SW.  2.) I find with one other person the challenge is about identical or slightly harder than the single player experience.  3.) He hosts the server in US and I connect from AUS. I definitely have lag but rubberband only rarely. The lag is consistent but isn't actually noticeable until you're trying to kite fight monsters, you generally can get one less hit off than if you weren't lagging. The lag is smooth (if that makes sense) and doesn't feel bad (and I usually abhor even minor lag). Compared to a year or so ago rubberbanding is largely gone and lag is less of an issue.  4.) I didn't know dedicated servers were a thing as someone else mentioned in this thread, maybe that would solve the lag issues. Will have to try it out.  5.) Most mods I have tried in singleplayer work with Don't Starve Together as well. We use mostly basic mods like minimaphud, colored wormholes, alwaysshowvalues, etc.  6.) It is definitely a complete, challenging, and highly highly enjoyable game. I personally vastly prefer it to single player (which I love!) even despite my own lag issues. If anyone has any questions feel free to run them by me!

Don't Starve Together reminds me of what games used to be.  Brutal & enjoyable from the get go.  The multiplayer is my first experience with this game & both the wife & I have spent a lot of time in game yelling, shrieking & laughing our butts off at various things in our attempts to tackle these randomly generated worlds!  EVERY game has been different.  While being wonderful to look at it's very easy to pick up & just start playing.  Fumble your way through the first few days & eventually things start just slotting into place.  Add a few survival  tips from the Don't Starve community & you might make it through the first Winter.  The best part of Don't Starve Together in my opinion are the constant suprises that just keep coming even after 30+ hours playing, whether its environmental, or little interactions between items you had not realised, new mobs or finding out you can feed a pig to make him your little buddy to help chop wood!  Just great!  I find the game well balanced & extremely challenging simply on default settings.  I would recommend to anyone that enjoys games with a murderous & brutal sense of humour for the art of survival.

This games lived to be miles above my expectations. With an extraordinary art style, unique game play and tactical thinking. You're not only trying to survive but you're trying to beat your own preious goals each time you begin a new server. Every day that passes you and your friends scurry off trying to gather as many supplies for the winter (and days ahead) and hope that your base is in a safe enough spot.   The multiplayer element really makes the game just as enjoyable as the single player version. With friends you're able to set goals and tasks to each person and team up in combats. PVP is a "hunger games" like experience. Seeing another player is frightening but an opportunity to team up and take on the server.  Modding for this game is highly accessible and easy to implement. The host of each server controls modding, so whatever mods they have installed, they will be the only ones avalible to use. Un-modded servers are available, however if you havn't played the single player version of Don't Starve I wouldn't recommend joining any un-modded serves. The game requires some getting used to and practice.  As you explore this vast land you'll encounter creatures, friendly beasts, mysterious entities and wonderful and scary abilities of Mother Nature and the human body. Highly reccomended, good luck and Don't Starve.

Don't Starve Together: An early access game that could well be a full game.  WARNING: Only buy if willing to be completely [strike] screwed up [/strike]  messed up horribly with/by your friends.  Pros: [list] [*] Multiplayer Support (obviously) [*] Extra Features from the original [*] Good servers- haven't ever had a server error [*] Teaches you to stab everything that comes near you, and to be as unsustainable as possible to survive- Good life lessons! [*] Can play 'singleplayer' if you want- ie. a world on your own. [*] You can troll people when you die! Yay! [/list]  Cons: [list] [*] Can destroy friendships. See warning above. [*] Some bugs [*] Can be quite laggy, depending on the host. [/list]  All in all, a great multiplayer game, as long as you're willing to take the risk of having your friends on.

Bought Don't Starve a while ago and loved it. I heard about the developers introducing multiplayer into it and got estatic! They were called, Optimus Pine and Bumbletree. They brought them along wherever they went. They defeated all sorts of foes, tenticals from the swamps, spiders from their nests, pigs from their houses. They were unstopable. They founded the Autostumps, a faction made of treeguards desitined to protect the very little humanity this place had to offer.  Sadly Shares5 and Zagger accidentally haunted them and they all burnt down. Autostumps are very flamable...

If you like original 'Don't Starve', you are likely to fall for this one as well. Here's pros and cons of this game: Pros: Get to play Don't Starve in multiplayer. Also RoG contents are included/in process (still beta after all) Cons: Host-guest game sync issues (latency). Some bugs since still in development. Major bug is where server is no longer joinable by others or particular players. Many times not good game experience with strangers. Too many noobs. :p  Updated: Jan 2, 2016 @ 3:52pm ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Klei is still making more contents! This really amazes me. Playing this game since the beta, I thought after official release from beta, no more contents would be made after fixing bugs. But game continues to add contents. Contents with background stories that puzzles players. The lores and the mysteries that it entails. Its amazing. Very in dept of a game. It takes a form of what is a survival roguelike RPG into deeper and deeper stage buildling on top of it. Who knows it might turn out to be something like of MMORPG? It has limitless potential. Only truely skilled players may be able to conquer the game to its depts.  Updated: Aug 17, 2017 @ 11:37pm

Don't Starve is a stylish survival game focused mostly on a hunger system. I explained in a previous review how it's a good game.   Don't Starve Together is just a multiplayer version of that game. There are some tweaks to it that better fit a multiplayer experience. There are many Workshop mods including custom characters. The only downside is that several of the more recent Don't Starve singleplayer updates haven't made it into the game, including some characters. But they are all included in mods anyway.

Don't Starve Together. I remember I spent two whole days playing this, non stop. It's really fun! Infact I still play it today. I can't stop playing it. I love the atmosphere, music, players, enemies, magic (ESPECIALLY MAGIC :D), etc. The community also helps make this game even more fun by creating mods for the game itself. I would help create modss, though I am not good at that ._.  There isn't anything I can really say about this game that is bad. Everything is so perfect! Though there is one problem. From my experience some of the ancient biomes are not in the game, no matter how many times you create a new world. I loved these biomes but they aren't in here. Or at least I have yet to actually get to one of them. So if that could be added. Awesome!  Overall this game is a 9/10 for me.

Don't Starve Together is what I always dreamed of when i first bought the single-player Don't Starve. The SP game was good, i was having a good time with it, but it always felt like something was missing, and, with me preferring Coop over Single-player, I HAD to get DST.  [b]PROs[/b](Assuming you already have Don't Starve SP) -ALL from your beloved Don't Starve, but with one or more friends. -You can use all the characters from the start(Except for some not-yet-implemented ones) -The multiplayer aspect is really well-programmed overall. -It has the Steam Workshop so you can use mods in your servers. -Character emotes.  [b]CONs[/b] : -I was experiencing really slow loads and more fps drops than with the SP one.  Well, the game is still a Beta, and it's going great right now.I can't ask for anything better from it :)  [h1]Vote: [b]9/10[/b][/h1] A must-buy for every Don't Starve fan.

Hands down one of the greatest survival games I have ever played. Between its vast majority of places to explore, character variety, and constant additions, the Don't Starve game series is one I'll never get tired of. Every game you join or world you create you discover something new, or are forced to play in a different way to adapt and survive.  Many survival games, once you get the hang of it, it doesn't stay much of a "survival" game. But with Don't Starve Together there are many situations that you may not expect to happen that can catch you off guard, such as the newer bosses constantly being added, getting ambushed while exploring the caves, or even just running out of resources forcing you to rely on your wits, instantly putting you back into the game.   The Klei developers themselves are also amazing people, I have seen them time and time again actually talk to those who play the game so people's voices are actually heard, and they are constantly adding new things to the game. I would recommend this game to anyone who wants a completely refreshing and new twist on the survival game genre, and wants more of a challenge out of their games. 10/10

Don't Starve Together's fun factor is essentially a multiple of the original Don't Starve.  Hunt and salvage for food, build a base to shelter oneself from the dangers of the Don't Starve world...but this time together.  Don't Starve Together is undisputably one of the best multiplayer survival games out there right now even in its beta state.  TL;DR - Took a stroll near base, got ganked by penguins. 10/10  ---  My last review was when the game was EA but I'm happy to say that DST continues to impress with ongoing development 'A New Reign' which is completely free!  ---  25/11/18  What?? This game is still getting free updates? The Forge!

Welp, if you played original Don't Starve and have doubts wether or not you should buy this game, you should do it. it's fun, it has public servers so you can jump on other people's games, and if you play with friends it's really fun to have that feeling of surival with them.  But now with the cons. KEEP IN MIND THIS IS EARLY ACCESS AND THIS MIGHT CHANGE IN THE FUTURE. But personally, i'm  not really fund of having this sensless survival. like, if you played original Don't Starve, there's at least an objective, something you have to do other than survive. but in this game it's simply...survive, or as the game says, Don't Starve. it might change in the future, but currently it hasn't .  and something that honestly ruins the experience is the whole ghosts thing. basically when other people die they turn into ghosts and even if they're really far away, it will slowly drain your sanity. and this bothers a lot specially in PvP servers. because what's the point of fighting everyone if after they die their ghosts will drain your sanity. so really, this would be a good idea, but only if ghosts are close to you not when they're 1000 miles away. but keep in mind this might be subject to change.  So why give this a good review with this specific cons? because the game's not completely finished. who knows, maybe in the future we will get objectives and the ghosts will be nerfed. but even if that doesn't happen, this game is fun to play from time to time and it can get pretty fun, specially when playing with friends.  as it is right now, I give this game 8/10

This game is hilarious.  At times it can be punishing, but through settings can be more manageable for those looking for less of a challenge. While I think it's more enjoyable to play the co-op version with a friend, it doesn't mean the single player experience isn't worth checking out.  I haven't experienced co-op through the public roulette of open servers -- so I can't speak to the experience of finding a game and playing it that way.  If you do, just know that you'll need a solid chunk of time to devote toward getting futher in the game.  You can save your co-op progress for future shenanigans if you need to hit the proverbial pause button.  Solid game.

However, I'd like to give a brief warning to anyone who wants to stream this with OBS. My laptop shut down on me three times in the course of a three hour session of playing DST on Twitch, due to running OBS, DST, and Discord voice chat at the same time.  I had to kinda brute force my way back into it every time I turned my laptop back on, but in the end I still had a fun time.  tl;dr : I like this game, be careful streaming it on a laptop. Issues can pop up quickly.

Edit:   Still absolutely love this game and Klei - please, never change, you're giving me hope when it comes to my relationship with game studios!   This game is immensely fun.  I love sandbox games with survival aspects, I do love 7 days to day, I enjoy Minecraft every now and then, but this game is just special. It is extremely hard at the beginning the game might seem very hard, almost impossible to survive (if you're not going through YouTube tutorials on how to survive, which I strongly recommend - finding everything out on yourself is half of the fun), but later on you'll get a grip of it. You might even survive the winter and then move on.  Now that was the description of classic single player don't starve - this one however's got Reign of Giants included, where spring is making you constantly wet, thus making you go insane, freezing and getting killed by enormous tornado attack ability having gooses... And that's considered a friendly season. It does make the game frustrating from time to time, but it's SO MUCH FUN'  TL;DR: You'll die a lot. You will have to learn a whole lot of things to do, to survive. You WILL die a lot. The game is gonna try to continuously make your life more and more miserable and you sure as hell WILL die a lot. But when you actually survive for 150 days plus or something, you're going to feel like it was all worth it.  Original, Epic, Fun and overally Brilliant

So, to start with this review I want to say that this game is definately one of the most fascinating ones. First and foremost, this game is really fun and enjoyable to play with friends. I remember when my brother showed me the single-player version of the game and I was so amazed. The graphics are very nice and fancy, the music is relaxing and depending on the situation it changes to match the 'background' . If you like survival games to play with friends, I definately recommend this game. On the other hand, once you get familiar with the game it starts to get boring and you can survive indefinately and once you collect most of the resources, build a base, explore the whole map (including caves) there is bassicaly nothing left to do.   Pros: -Really enjoyable with friends -Great music -Many customizations through workshop -Nice gameplay and mechanics Cons: -Poor online servers -Game gets boring after you get good at is since you can survive indefinately -Poor PVP (needs some gamemodes or something) This sums up my review, I hope you found it helpfull! :)

Don't Starve was one of my favorite survival games when it came out, and multiplayer has breathed new life into a game I already adored. The addition of extra players, plus tweaking of existing mechanics balanced around multiplayer and an incentive to keep your companions alive, makes the game very fun and leads to a lot of memorable moments, especially with friends (like when they're insane and being attacked by monsters only they can see, and you're chasing them trying to force-feed them jerky to make them regain their sanity and make the monsters stop attacking).  If you enjoyed Don't Starve, and you have friends who also enjoy Don't Starve, this is great fun and I highly recommend it. If you want to play online without friends, do so at your own risk - the community is varied at best.  p.s. Connections can be finnicky at times, but the game is generally quite playable and rubberbanding is very uncommon. There's never any real desyncing issues with the host, and most mods work clientside and won't affect the host.

This game is by far the best wilderness survival game with rogue-like elements. There's so much to learn and craft, it seldom gets old and boring for new players. It's awesome yet simultaneously annoying; you can bring giants to their knees but still die from a damned frog (if you don't play carefully). So basically it's an amazing game, especially for fans of the wilderness survival and crafting genre looking for unforgiving co-op play.

A fun survivalal game that is easy to learn but difficult to master. Its fun to both play by yourself and others. The world has seasons and two of the seasons (Spring and Fall) are relatively easy to survive, while the other two seasons are more challenging (Summer and Winter). You need to spend your time wisely in Spring and Fall to make it through Summer and Winter. If you like survival games, you will likely enjoy this one. This game can be challenging at first, but stick with it! It's a lot of fun and its especially fun to play with friends. Try to play through an entire year so you can get a feel for all the seasons with all of its unique challenges and monsters. Then make your own custom games with the options you enjoy the most and invite your friends to play.

If you're looking for a really great game to play with a bunch of your friends, I highly suggest Don't Starve Together. While the base game itself is enduring, I really got the kicks out of it when playing multiplayer.  Pros: - Dozens of mods to subscribe to (new characters, objects, tools, etc) - Very beautiful art style / music scheme going on - it's very easy to fall in love with the aesthetics.  - If you haven't played the game before, it'll likely pose quite a challenge (even with friends!).  - Klei occasionally updates the game, adding / changing details to make it more difficult   Cons: - After awhile, you will pick up on the pattern of the game. Unfortunately, it'll get insanely easy and might bore you (I'm talking like 30+ hours, however). Nonetheless, Klei offers the ability to make it harder if you'd please (e.g more enemies, less valuable resources. I found living in a swamp or a cave to be more difficult).

Well, Don't Starve Together. I love this game, and I don't think I need to point out why, over 30 thousand people have already pointed it out. Impeccable music, unique and incredible art style, brutal yet rewarding gameplay. I have to say, it's hard to stop playing this game, and not in a Skinnerbox method, Candy Crush/WoW kind of "I can't stop playing." I'm a total survival + sandbox game junkie, and this fills both of those needs. It's hard for me to name a single problem with this game itself, but I'll get to the problems with it that aren't Klei's fault later on.   ---The Game Itself, and what it's like.--- The game is a blast, full of tough decisions, engaging gameplay, and stress. Lots of stress. Don't Starve Together has you managing a few main things, this being your HP, your Hunger, your Sanity, your temperature, your wetness, and probably most importantly, time. You need to go throughout the world, collecting any resource you can simply to survive. Survive intervals of hound attacks, which get more frequent as time goes on. Survive full moons, where normally friendly pigmen become ...werepigs. Spooky. You'll travel throughout an unforgiving world and eventually set up a camp where you can unlock new recipes to help you survive. Later on, winter will start. In this, plants grow more slowly, days are shorter, nights are longer, and you can very easily freeze.  After a long time, you can improve your base and make surviving "easier". It's a grand world of fear and surprises, I'm only scraping the surface.  ---Playing Singleplayer--- Playing singleplayer is great, but if you wanted to do that, Don't Starve is better for it. It's considerably easier, and it even has another gamemode, Don't Starve Shipwrecked that... Well, I'm getting off topic. Singleplayer is great, but it's not where Don't Starve Together is centered.  ><~~~Playing Multiplayer~~~><      Ooh, fancy.  Multiplayer is where Don't Starve Together both shines and falls flat. If you gather some friends and make a private server, it's a total blast! Some of the most fun I've had in a while. Spoiler alert, having food isn't as easy with 6 people. You can survive together, help each other, and if one of you dies, one can revive another for a relatively small price. Truly, in multiplayer, cooperation is key. And that's exactly why public multiplayer is the only real flaw in the game.  The game's community, if you haven't heard about it before, is... Well, it's something else. Over half of the people who play the game are imbecilic and lazy, or just game-ruining for a good laugh. If they don't play well or even decently, they're probably stealing your stuff, destroying your base, or literally just sitting around doing nothing!  True story if you care to listen, actually, I was once in a server that made it until late winter. We even defeated the deerclops, a major boss in Don't Starve. One of the players who lived in our base hadn't really accomplished much. The player that had helped our base grow the most was asking him politely to do something, and he didn't respond. I gave him a golden axe, and asked him to chop some trees for logs. He took it, and did nothing, instead asking for food. The other person started yelling at him to do something. Again, he did absolutely nothing. We ended up kicking him.  It gets MUCH worse than that, however. People just join, ask if they can join your base, or asking for key resources, with varying levels of grammatical errors. If you refuse, they'll give a quick "f*** u ur a n00b" and then proceed to either leave, or whine and complain until kicked, or until they inevitably die because they weren't actually playing the game.  ~~~Conclusion/TL;DR~~~ DST is an incredible game blending fun mechanics and stressful decisions. You definitely should buy it if you have friends willing to play with you. If not, then buying the singleplayer Don't Starve would be better... This game isn't worth it for public multiplayer. About 1 in every 6 servers you join will have a decent game waiting for you. Just about everything in the game itself is flawless... If you can take the community.  So, get ready for a fun night with friends. Deal with sanity, monsters, hounds, and especially other players. But most of all... Don't Get Caught Out In The Darkness Without A Torch. Can't wait for that game.
Dont buy it unless you have a few free weeks. Insanely addictive!

An unique game that has managed to create a new experience. Even thought the artwork is awesome and may make you feel comfortable, this is one of the most stressing games I've ever played.  It starts cool, slow and easy. But don't get fooled, pass some days and you'll discover that every day it gets harder to live, to the point where you're sure to get more stressed than pleased. But that is part of the fun. It is worth every second.  Besides the artwork, the sound effects are very well made. The environment is rich, so pay attention to every detail. The lore is very cool, and there are many mysteries to discover. In fact, this game is so rich in content, that every time you play you may discover something new. Besides that, there are a great amount of mods for it.  The recent rotation of events are bringing new life to the game, making it very renewed.  You'll never forget the experience of playing this game with some good friends.  If you like crafting and having many trouble surviving out there, you should play this. If don't, you should play it too.  9/10

Don't Starve Together is a great survival game, and one of the few games where survival is actually a challenge. This game has a high skill ceiling, and definitely takes time and practice. Playing with a friend will really make the game more fun as well. Now, here are the positives and negatives.  [b] Positives [/b]  -Tons of content -4 Seasons (all have their own content/challenges) -High skill ceiling (very hard and unforgiving) -Many characters with unique personalities and abilities -Skins for customization, plus Ancient King skins (which you need a friend to get them) -Many enemies and creatures, all with unique designs. -Incredible, Tim Burton atmosphere -Caves, which have loads of new stuff including the Ruins. -Sailing on boats, with islands to explore, colonize, etc. -Tons of different types of food to create (via crockpot) -Events such as the Forge and Gorge -Passionate devs who really care about the game.   [b] Negatives [/b]  -Absolutely no tutorial, this game relies on trial-and-error -After a full in-game year, there isn't much to do besides mega-base -DLC Characters. Very few, but definitely don't feel like they belong in this type of game. -Skins are pretty overpriced. On com. market, it's about $1 or less. However, the skins Klei offer are locked behind $3 to $5 prices which I think is overboard. Not much of an issue tho.   To conclude, this game is super fun, especially with friends. I do implore you to find an experienced friend to teach you, or practice a lot. It is hard at the start, and frustrating. You will struggle, that is a given. That is what the game is about, struggling. Keep playing, practicing, and you will only get better. Remember, the important thing to keep in mind is to have fun. Don't cherish your belongings/base, this isn't the type of game for that. You will make new worlds a lot, don't be discouraged. This is normal. Anyways, good luck, and Don't Starve!

Don't Starve Together is one of my favourite multiplayer survival games. Although hard to get into (to begin with) players will quickly become a fan of the survival game. Because the game is difficult for newer players the game is highly configurable to make what started off as something of an impossible feat to something much more fun and easy. The game's community is very creative and there are hundreds of community-made mods for you to try out and change your experience! You can either play cooperatively or turn the tables and enable PvP where you will build, survive, defend and kill.  In conclusion, Don't Starve Together is an amazing game and I recommend it to anyone that has friends to play it with!

My most recommended game; that said it's not for everyone.  Unlike most other games in this genre, it's not a resource grind--in fact, it requires you to spend your time efficiently and to think ahead to survive.  Survival actually always feels like a threat if you ever stop thinking.  In that sense, can be like a psychological war of attrition (which I love).  Also, I love the atmosphere and the characters: dark, yet whimsical; each demanding a change in your play style as you learn to work with their strengths and weaknesses.  Gets lots of developer love (somewhat to the exclusion of its single-player older brother), even including support for multiplayer using community-created mods and finding other players.  If you think you might like this, also check out Oxygen not Included, also by Klei (singleplayer).

This is simply the BEST survival game that you will EVER play, with friends or with people online. No other survival game really comes close to matching the aspect of "surviving" in DST.  The game is set in a beautiful, dark world where you choose a character with unique abilities to play with. You will begin the game with little to nothing, and you will have to figure out what you have to do to keep your character staying healthy and alive. Darkness, hunger, mobs, insanity, and the wrath that comes with each season of the year will kill you if you’re not careful.  As you learn more about how to survive in the game — through other players, by yourself, or through the helpful Don’t Starve wiki — you will survive more easily, and you will become better equipped to tackle tougher challenges, such as helping to kill big bosses such as Deerclops, or venturing deep down into the Caves to look for greater treasure. You will learn how to be as efficient as possible at base-building, food-making, item-crafting, and resource-collecting. Or, if you are not the efficient-type, you will enjoy wandering around the Don’t Starve world with a Garland on your head, Chester by your side, collecting Berries to eat, and picking flowers along the way. Or, if you just want in-game Skins, you can semi-afk to collect them, which you use to customize your character with, or trade away in the Steam Market for money.  Replayability is wonderful in this game. With every new playthrough, you will challenge yourself to do better than before, and you will encounter new survival techniques. However, you will always be susceptible to dying. Even with the numerous hours of experience that I and other players have, we will still die to unfortunate and/or unforeseen circumstances, and it will be hilarious.  All in all, a fantastic and beautiful multiplayer survival game made by Klei. The developers imbue this game with a lot of heart and love, and they continue to do so with the new events and updates. <3

There is Plenty to do in the game, especially when you play with friends. Enough content (and more being added) in the base game, and if you want more, you can change it up how much you want in the workshop by downloading mods for it.  I don't die much unless I'm killed by a random player, but when unlucky events do happen, or when you first start the game (Not used to the gameplay), I'd say this is one of those games with a slight Love/Hate relationship. You die over and over yet you can never hate the game. Not nearly as love/hate-ie as the first game though, Don't Starve, the Single Player Only game, as when you died there, heh, sucks for you!  The game sticks around Multiplayer gameplay, meaning all Boss HP is increased from the first game, as they're meant to have more people beating on them, I've Noticed that hunting rabbits (expecially with traps) makes it to where they don't respawn the next day or sometimes longer meaning that if there's alot of players eating the same food, you'll run out.  Basically, certain things may be more easy when you play alone, but yet when you play with others you'll get further, Because it IS a multiplayer game and that's what they stuck to.  The game isn't very glitchy at all. I have noticed a few here and there, but they're all "Personal" glitches as I call them, meaning: Only certain people get them and still have them even after disabling all mods and redownloading the game. (Example: I can't hear certain mobs, I sometimes crash out of the blue, "Don't Starve Together Has Stopped Responding")   I wouldn't say that's a problem on the game's part for now, but as some other people have "Certain glitches", Maybe not exactly mine, it may be.  Over all, this game is REALLY fun. It's a big step from the Single Player version, and (With the Beta) has pretty cute content c;   Though I would recommend more SMALLER mobs, as not everyone fights those raid bosses. Yes, Baby pets and No-eyed Deer have been added to NR Beta, but there's not alot you can do with those...and rabbits, for example, are getting a bit boring.

Don't starve together (DST) is very good survival game which doesn't need good PC to play. It may be boring for You if you don't have friends to play with, but community is nice so you should find some people to play with. It's like Don't starve (DS) with DLC Reign of giants (RG) but you can play with friends, there are costumes (You get them from presents while playing on server) which you can buy and sell on community market. I will show you cons and pros to buy this game:  +Nice survival game +Low PC requirements +It's DS but with friends  +Mods and costumes +Caves and free DLC (RG)  -Sometimes you can feel bugs -Without gamepad it's hard to play it -After some time it may be boring for some people.  I recommend this game for lovers of survival multiplayer games and for people who just want to have fun with friends.

Really fun and addictive game, but also very frustrating when you die.   I love this game. I reccomend this game, but be prepared to die a lot when you first start out and know that you can lose all of your progress at any moment... but that's half of the fun :')   Pros:  - Fun game, you can easily sink many hours into it.  - Very rewarding when you finally get it right and start to build a decent camp, gather supplies and the like.  - Great for playing with friends, or with strangers to create larger settlements and survive. - Lots to discover, I'm still finding new things as I explore.  - Unique, quirky art style.  - Cool monsters.  Cons: - The online multiplayer element of the game means that you cannot pause the game (you have to leave the game and come back, if you leave the keyboard you could lose everything before you get back) and you cannot save file in the traditional sense. This makes dying very frustrating, especially if you were doing well.  - Brutal game, everything wants to kill you and sometimes this gets too much.

Very fun and addictive survival game where you can team up with your friends and try to survive in the wilderness against monsters, hunger, darkness and cold and keep yourself from losing your mind in the process.  Pros: + There is no perfect class. All classes have one or more weakspot aswell as one or more strength that counters another. All depends on your play-style what you want to go with. + I tend to have trouble creating servers and having my friends connect to those but on this game I have seen none of those problems. + Plenty of different game modes to fit to your preferred play-style. + The game rewards you with cosmetic items every once in a while to customise your character. + Countless hours of fun with your friends  Cons: - There seems to be no way of tracking your friends. When you reach a certain distance you lose track of their location. I ran around for ages joining my friend's server trying to find him and his camp until I eventually died in the dark. Add some way of partying up and maybe something that shows in which direction and how far away from you they are. - The game could use a tutorial. If you only just started playing your only help is checking the key-bindings. - Public servers are full of territorial hermits that will guard their camp at every cost and will not take friendly to intruders. (Even when the server clearly states it's Co-op).

Playing Don't Starve can be infuriating. There's absolutely no guidance, and the initial punishing difficulty only increases. It demands that players figure things out for themselves and progress through exploration and experimentation rather than being spoonfed hints and tips. Its uncompromising nature will undoubtedly leave some unsatisfied and irritated, but for those who are willing to work and take risks, it pays off.

Did you guys notice the pun in the game's title? Don't Starve TO GET HER(Charlie) ;)  I've been playing Don't Starve since, about 2014 or 2015, I also recieved the beta version of this for free, and been playing since.  I gotta say, this game takes a really unique style to survival genres! I love the artstyle, the music is pleasant to listen to (besides ragtime, god is that hell to listen to for hours.), the characters are unique and in my view aren't broken in any way. Like you hear from others, it's MUCH more fun playing with friends! I honestly love how the continued the lore from the classic Don't Starve, and made it really interesting. I hope I can see more content in the lore from Klei, as it would be amazing! Anything else added like items would be amazing too.  And that people say that "this game has no tutorial, therefore I do not reccomend" or say "Omg it's soooo hard to survive, such a lame game, it sucks!!11!1!!" and honestly, don't even review the game if you can't figure out how to play or just look up guides.   Alright, time to get to the Pros and Cons.  Pros +Art Style is unique! +Music is great. +Love the customization in outfits! +It supports mods, to make it fresh. +Fun with friends. +Buying outfits are cheap. +No trolls (that burn bases), atleast for me. +So far, the expierence with support is superb!  Cons -Hard for someone that is new and doesn't know how to play. -The gift boxes for outfits rarely give any good outfits, they should make it so the more you open in a week, the more chances to get really good outfits. -Honestly, it does get a bit tedious after awhile if you can't make it to even summer. -You can't do much more if you can't add caves, which requires much more to run it. (Besides running in singleplayer or something)  (My Personal cons that don't count) =Not really that fun if you're a pro playing with a noob that you have to carry around like an extra bag of stones =Honestly, there are WAY too many people who join my servers and after I make base, they just stay there claiming to be "taking care of the base" when they just sit there cooking food in crockpots for no reason, and just eating it all. I know I can ban them and all, but it honestly feels so rude that I don't. =Hell, I haven't even gotten past summer myself! =There are also people who join servers that have a ton of days on, and don't do anything because they like being free fed and doing nothing for it. =Really hard to join servers that are hosted by strangers because I'm shy asf, so I just kinda hover around a bit. (STILL PLAY THE GAME THOUGH) =Barely anyone joins my server :( =Also, most fuckin' mods that are for DST are so cringe, like Undertale, anime, and furries, they get so much positivity for not atleast trying to make an original character (or just self inserting themselves).  Still, Great flippin' game overall, I LOVE it so much!!! Probably about a 9/10 for me. (I'm sorry if I offend anyone, it's just my opinion I'm putting out there on my review for a game)

o you guys need a chocolate chip cookie recipe? - Ingredients  3/4 cup granulated sugar SAVE $ 3/4 cup packed brown sugar SAVE $ 1 cup butter or margarine, softened SAVE $ 1 teaspoon vanilla 1 egg SAVE $ 2 1/4 cups Gold Medal™ all-purpose flour 1 teaspoon baking soda 1/2 teaspoon salt 1 cup coarsely chopped nuts 1 package (12 ounces) semisweet chocolate chips (2 cups) Steps 1 Heat oven to 375ºF. 2 Mix sugars, butter, vanilla and egg in large bowl. Stir in flour, baking soda and salt (dough will be stiff). Stir in nuts and chocolate chips. 3 Drop dough by rounded tablespoonfuls about 2 inches apart onto ungreased cookie sheet. 4 Bake 8 to 10 minutes or until light brown (centers will be soft). Cool slightly; remove from cookie sheet. Cool on wire rack.

One of my favourite games, nearly all resources are renewable and the changes to some characters definately suit the "together" playstyle. This game can still be played on your own (which i tend to do often) and is just great if you like a little challenge and change the world generation to suit your needs. New to the game and finding it difficult to survive? Turn up the ratio of resources spawning and decrease the amount of foes spawning. Want a challenge? Try "Lights Out" mode for an intense world of darkness. Overall, tremendous game

[h1]A Real Review[/h1]  [h1]Pro's:[/h1] Multiplayer Non-Stop Fun with Friends Low requirements Buy and Play  [h1]Con's:[/h1] Workshop Mod Errors no-matter what Crashes (Dont know why) Boring with no friends  [h1]Detailed Review:[/h1] Reminder this is a real review!  Don't Starve Together is like a big update for the original game Don't Starve, I suggest buying this because there the same but with multiplayer. Server's are easy to make and easy too find. Ton's of endless fun with friends, but the Workshop Errors get annoying I had a friend look through the error's and it is a Lua Script error and he cannot fix it however I do not think this is a problem with the game more a problem with the Developer of the Mod. But, a way too fix this issue is when you get the error and the Option either Leave the game or Disable Mods on top of it, it shows the list of mods enabled. Replace that with the mod(s) causing the error so the player/owner can delete it or contact the dev who made it too fix it. This is the only problem I find with the game but everything is great!   I would give this a Positive score  [h1]9.2/10[/h1]

As someone who's played quite a bit of single player the option to play with others is an amazing upgrade, though there are some downsides.  Pros- Get to play with other people Allows you to host a server (no hamachi bs) A lot of new content not found in singleplaywr Cons - hard to find a permanent public server, once you log off you probably won't find it again Possibility of world resetting while you're offline Connection issues    All in all, get it if you have friends willing to play with you, otherwise you might just end up server hopping a lot

原版已经是非常吸引人的一款独立游戏了，多人模式把乐趣又提升一个等级，拉上朋友或者情侣一起在饥荒的世界里，从采集开始，到建立领地，准备过冬，探险作死，各种欢乐的体验都相当有趣，强烈建议不要上网查看攻略，多人一起探索和冒险真的是很棒的体验。  Klei Entertainment 特立独行的彩绘风格和诙谐的对白也为这个作品也加分不少，硬要说缺点的话就是当你探索和熟悉了所有的东西之后，所拥有的乐趣也会相对减少，当然官方持续地在做内容更新，各种民间mod也很有趣，社区发展相当良好，总之呢，买了就不会亏。  如果你喜欢生存游戏，强烈推荐，拉上你的小伙伴，一起加入饥荒的世界吧。

2/17/2015  Be careful with mods. Seriously. I tried uninstalling and reinstaling, and it still crashes every time I try to host a server... even without mods now. Keep in mind this game isn't finished. It's worth buying to support development, and even now it has plenty to make the purchase worthwhile. Controller support exists, but it's still in testing. You will have to hover your mouse over some menu options, like in settings or in the mod menu... but then you can use the Dpad to navigate. The settings menu requires you to hover your mouse over something that won't change value when you press A, in order to SAVE SETTINGS. Had to figure this out the hard way, no big deal... I'm sure they'll fix all these issues later... but even still, a controller feels great with this game, once you get used to the navigation issues. The in-game UI threw me off, but it makes a lot of sense once you feel it. I personally love it, the whole game. Atmosphere, music, controls, menu systems (that work), art style, and mod support! This game will go far! <3  9/10

Don't Starve Together, The Real Insanity Inducing Game!    Recommended cause Webber with the backpack is just too damn cute not to recommend, otherwise holy s**tballs it's as tedious as hell! Edit: Playing with mods makes it somewhat easier (and better in my opinion), but honestly even if you love the graphics, it's not for casual players, it's worse than doing a Boss 20+ times on Dark Souls but atleast you can have 6 friends (or more with dedicated servers) to do it with, and honestly that's only what i would recommend, 5+ friends for casual players.  I recommend this game as it is what it is, but don't be fooled by the cute graphics, it's harsh, your either freezing to death or overheating, if you survive that while getting resources some big ass giant will turn up each year to wipe what you build out, unless you proactively lure it away.  Finding out what you need to build and what you should keep makes it all so much worse, as not only is the above tedious trying to plan ahead with little knowledge of all the things ingame makes you want to throw your PC out the window!

I played this game with my friends when it was just released, but not on steam and now I have it, so whats about this game?  It's simple game with nice graphics and drawed-painted stuff, that makes game very original and enjoyable to play. Every time I play it I'm getting more and more experienced, and somethimes I'm just surprised by this game logic, because It's teaching me real survival things, that might actually help in survival situations. This game also have funny characters and interesting events, where you can get very nice items while doing events. Also there's in-game drops. You can get 4 drops a week total, sometimes even expesive ones. This game also has workshop, so you can add some mods, like minimap or display enemy HP, food values and more.  Is this game worth getting? Yes. I also reccomend getting shipwrecked and reign of giants DLCs RECOMMEDED

One day i was playing the game when i realized i made a horrible mistake.   I was looking to upgrade my techs all over the map, but i completely forgotten to pick at least a single hay stack so i could build a torch to save for my life from the Darkness [i] (Yes it kills) [/i]   Then whiteout ways to built a torch, i would have to endure it until i die.   Im hopeless. There is notinhing i can do... whiteout a torch death is certain.   When the darkness came, and creatures of the night haunted my mind...  There was all but hope in my life.   I gave myself to the darkness,  And as if god had heard my plea...  I got saved by a matter of RNG.   Fireflies appeared out of nowhere, lightining a small circle that could save my life.   I had under 2 seconds to move to the source of all life, and i barely managed to survive.   Until the light of the fireflies begun to fade.   [i] WHAT NOW MY GOD [/i]   Then i saw there was not one firefly around...  [i] There was just more than enough to keep me alive. [/i]   I decided to dance whitin the darkness, Embracing the light and darkness aside,   Until the terror of the night ended and i could survive once more.   Once i realized the Randomness of the game can kill,   But also ensure the survival of many in desperate times,  [h1] I had no choice but to write a positive review for this game [/h1]

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

TL;DR I give this game a 7/10.  Do I recommend this? Yes* (*)Only worth picking up on sale and if you have a friend to play it with. It still gets stale pretty fast.  Story  - This game has no narrative, so...absent. Sound - Pretty good atmospheric sounds and ambience. Gameplay - There's a minimal sense of progression but all of it can be robbed of you pretty quickly. Without a leveling up system it leaves you feel like most games are a rush to get the best items and to hold out, like a surival game-lite moba. Replayability - Fair, but I'd still prefer Haven and Hearth over this. Positives:  +Attractive (if not a meme at this point) art style +Decent entry into the wave of survival-esque games +Cool sound effects +Doesn't require a gaming computer to run +Pick up and play +unlockable loot crate style items are more an ambiguous "positive" but it adds replayability Negatives: -Very weak combat system -Brutal winters unless you shorten them, thereby playing on a weaker difficulty setting -Griefers and player killers are abound on most non PVE servers -no strong sense of progression -no achievements  Final Verdict: I don't regret paying for it but I dont see myself playing DST very often with all the other survival type games out there that don't look like they were made in flash.

Grass! Twigs! Berries! DEATH.  The name kinda tells you the base of the games objective but what you don't know is the depth of what you can and have to do to not starve. BUT NOW YOU CAN DO IT WITH FRIENDS!!  Find berries. death, carrots or kill animals for various types of meat that will fill your belly and even make you go insane! Depending on what food you eat, or how to prepare and cook it (by mixing it with other food and using a crock pot) it will restore more health, fill your hunger or increase/decrease your sanity bar. If you have the DLC (Reign of Giants) you will also have to deal with overheating and freezing to death (the freezing one is also in the base game)   Surviving is what your new life is about in this hellish new world. Find food, fight off monsters and hunger while always trying to keep yourself from going insane. Your food bar is always going down, forcing you to find food to fill your mighty belly. Health goes down when struck by enemies, eating rotten food or depending on your character (will talk about that below) damaged by certain specific events (like rain.) Watch your heat so you don't freeze to death, allowing your temp reach 0 or below will deal damage to you. But when its summer, watch out that the heat so welcomed in the winter will not give you heat stroke, causing the same effects and will cause unwanted damage to your player. Finally, your sanity. Sanity is drained passively while near thingys (objectives in survival mode) being in the darkness, at night in general, being near enemies or eating spoiled food or bad food. In the multiplayer version, you will also have to deal with people killing you and stealing your items. Make sure you focus on a good defense or offense to protect all you have worked for.  Many types of food to make, plenty of resources to scavenge for and potentially very massive maps that give you tons of content to explore for weapons, clothing, gadgets and trinkets.  Several unique characters make replaying when you die worthwhile, if you hate wilson and his scientific beard, play as the robot who hates rain, or as the strong man, who is a bulldozer on steroids when his hunger is filled but becomes weaker when it is not.  Track your progress and "high scores" by tallying your days (it will do this by itself and give you exp for new characters this way but more for bragging rights) and try and pass them every attempt.   You will die, trust me. The first couple tries will kill you and if by some luck or amazing skill you made it far enough to see your first winter, that will kill you.   Modded characters are fun to play, all set with their own pros and cons, and most being very balanced and playable in-game. + most of the mods are very helpful, like tracking your stats better, keeping your items better stacked and allowing for easier travel.  Say hello to the shadow beasts for me ;)  Personal Rating: 4/5

This game is indeed innovative and unforgiving. Being kind of a gaming veteran from the days of Bard's Tale, no problem with that.  However, there are some points i did not like so much: First, the only way for us to get rid of lagging was a dedicated console server (this however works very well). Having to start a dedicated server is quite a piece of work, even though there is a docker image available.  Second, i really dislike games without a pause option. Its more or less impossible to leave your PC while running the game, this could have been handled better. Like using some kind of vote mechanism in multiplayer games.  While i really like the concept of the game, i cannot recommend the multiplayer version.

5/7 "its ok"  In all seriousness this is one of the best games I have ever played, of course like every game it has a community with very diverse players, some good, some bad, some very malicious and some that are saintly. My favorite thing is the skill gap of the game, it has a steep learning curve and despite knowing almost everything about the game I still find myself enjoying a different experience every single time I play. Its a very particular type of game, a mix of survival with sandbox, in early hours of playing you will find yourself fighting the game, but eventually you will have the power to set up environments and areas that are completely self sustaining and the game can become quite relaxing for the skilled player. Its nonetheless fun and I don't find myself getting bored of it anytime soon, especially with the devs still adding new content in.

Don't Starve Together is a nice, easy to play (but hard to master) fun survival permadeath game. I'd recommend it, except for one major problem.  With multiple people on the server, if you die you turn into a ghost. Somebody must use a Telltale Heart on you to revive you, or you will forever be a ghost and only be able to haunt people.  There's one major flaw with this; public servers. If you're in a public server just playing and don't have a friend to communicate with and give you a Telltale Heart, you are forever stuck as a ghost and can only haunt people until somebody decides to give you one. That is a TERRIBLE mechanic; it's a good idea except for the fact that you cannot respawn even if you want to. Maybe if you could respawn and just lose all your stuff versus being given a Telltale Heart and retaining it it would be okay, but the fact that if you, like me, were at 9 health running around in the night-time with a Blue Hound following you like a gay following his boyfriend endlessly until you are killed, and when it kills you you are eternally a ghost, makes it a terrible game.  Minus that fact, it's good.... but that is the most stupid thing ever. Don't Starve Together gives you the ability to host a dedicated server that is open for lots of players (who you don't necessarily know) but when you do that it punishes you by making it so if you die you must have another person to be able to revive you to be able to play the game, and if you don't, the world must be reset (for whatever reason) or you are forever Casper's twin.  P.S. this was a rage-induced review, so forgive me if I'm incorrect in any way. I'll probably give it a day and edit this to be positive so take it with a grain of salt if you can live with this major flaw in design.

Don't Starve, Africa edition, has brought fans of the series a well deserved addition, the ability to troll, I mean 'help' your 'friends'. You have so many ways to play this game, all leading to death. But that is the beauty of it. Every play through will have different problems, and in single player this will become a big issue. However the multiplayer brings with it multitasking. In the glorious first days you and your partner will build a close dependent bond which will break due to one player making a penis out of cow shit and die of laughter. The funny part here is that we died the next day due to a random encounter with an overpowered boss. My friend was mad, I was dying of laughter, our characters were dying in general, and memories were made. Guess what? We decided to play again, vowing the next world will be different. I love single-player Don't Starve. So does my sister. We decided to play it together. We can't.   No matter what we do, this game lags. Rubber-banding, getting hit by enemies from the opposite side of the screen, clicking something and failing to interact... you name the lag symptom, we've had it. We've tried everything to make it work: "no lag" mods, turning our computer settings to maximum power, not using cosmetic items, etc. Nothing works. Sometimes we can play for half an hour before the lag starts. Most of the time it starts within five minutes in the world. All of this even happens when we're on LAN.   Also, a small gripe: on the rare occasions we've gotten it to work, we discovered that thermal stones for winter now have durability in this version. Why? That's a horrible decision. It didn't add difficulty to the game, just annoyance.   Anyway. Lag. Can't play. Boo.

My rating is due to many often ignored cons about this game. For starters, the game is designed inherently to be played by casual gamers, however, the game is excessively punishing to casual players. You'll spend about 59 minutes out of every hour holding the A button and doing nothing else. The content of the game is tiny and isn't frequently updated enough to justify its current size and therefore, it has very small replay value. The game can be easily beaten in about 2 hours with most content unlocked. After you've beaten the game, the only way to continue playing it is to play it the same exact way you played it the other 3000 times you played it. The worst character in the game "willow" had a patch that nerfed her lighter, which wasn't even a good enough benefit to justify using her in the first place. Why nerf a character that's already virtually unplayable? Bad game design and decision making on a grand scale. There is a huge list I could pile onto the desk of other issues that face this game but most of that list would sound more like needless complaining rather than helpful information, so that's for you to speculate based on your own preferences and bias. However, the last thing I'll touch on is, the game is terrible with controller recognitions. If you use a PS controller, not only will the game treat it like Xbox, but in game, it will still instruct you to use a keyboard input rather than telling you which button on your controller to use. This can cause widespread confusion on new players and is often a complaint I see from them on different forums boards and other outlets. I'm done sacking on this game now. Enjoy.

I bought this game for me and my long-distance girlfriend to play together.  And it was exactly what we needed.  Something that required intellectual skill, but not technical skill.  In other words, I was looking for a game that wouldn't be hard to play for a novice gamer like my GF.  Because this game uses a point and click interface, it was perfect.  Also like I said, this game requires teamwork and smart decisions to be successful.  You must communicate with your teammate and pay attention to many details.  There is very little room for rest in this game, and I find myself satisfied after only a single round.  Essentially the goal of the game is to survive as long as possible.  To do this, some of the essential tasks will be finding or creating food, making clothing, resource gathering, staying warm, and fighting off monsters.  Items are crafted by gathering raw material and special items from the world such as grass, spider's silk, lumber, and minerals.  What's great about this game is its randomly generated terrain.  This essentially means you'll have to modify your strategy in every game.  Sometimes you'll be dropped in lush garden of eden.  Another time you may be dropped in a barren desert and have to travel a long ways to find a suitable campsite.  The ratios of fruits, raw material, and animals will also vary as well as their geographic location.  It's definitely a game of learning from mistakes and trail and error.  You'll learn to set goals to achieve in x number of days, avoid danger, memorize crafting recipes, prepare for sudden weather and monster attacks, and sustain yourself.  Be prepared to meet moments of indecision as there are many many items that can be crafted.  I recommend consulting the wiki as you learn more.  I'd recommend this to any one who likes co op games.  But for me personally, I was looking for a game that could be played with an SO with minimal gaming background, and Don't Starve hit the mark perfectly.

I've had amazing fun with this game for almost 200 hours and every time i took a break and came back there was always something new and exciting to try out thanks to the constant support. Yet i sadly cannot recommend this game anymore thanks to the pestilence plaguing the games industry that is lootboxes. At first this game handled lootboxes considerably better than most other implementations of RNG based microtransactions as all rewards were earned ingame, with [u]absolutely no in game store[/u] deviously manipulating you to buy packs, and it really did feel rewarding to open boxes unlike pretty much every other game using them. But now that those days are over any enjoyment i might get out of opening a lootbox is overshadowed by the pessimistic dread that accompanies these predatory monetization systems. I'd be fine with spending a little to help support the game if i didn't have to gamble for what i want, and even if lootboxes are not legally gambling, it is just as predatory and unethical. Call me a crybaby/entitled/overreacting, whatever you want but i stand by my principles and i simply cannot recommend this game anymore.

Don't starve together is certainly unforgiving. With no tutorial whatsoever, nor tooltips, the game seems to be built around exploration and tactics to survive. There are four seasons: Autumn, Winter, Spring, Summer. Autumn is the default with no environmental hazards. You heard me.  Each season sans autumn has an environmental hazard. Winter has its cold, threatening to kill you of frostbite. Spring has rain, driving the non-british characters of don't starve together (bloody yanks) to nuts and bolts. You might think summer would be the safest season. It is far from THAT! You'd need a lot of nitre and at least two thermal stones just to survive, as well as clever manipulation of underground and above ground resources. You should never waste resources in this game. Every single one counts.  Let me tell you something about spring - which killed me more than once. Spring rains are very common, requiring you to make an umbrella by killing a pig or finding a source of pig skin through pig heads/pig houses. Now, when you do make an umbrella, expect to be struck by lightning frequently lest you make a lightning rod. Yet even a lightning rod cannot protect you from the horrors of the French, Hon hon hon, they laugh as they fall out of the sky, killing you by surrounding you, then punching your private parts with the sheer force of their disgusting tongue. Wretched and evil is the tongue of the French, that it smells of stinky cheese and escargot. They need not even aim it directly at you - the sheer smell is enough to damage you. Their pilots are dangerous, dropping them off when visibility is low and our fighters cannot engage their transports. The battle is hard fought with your own infantrymen punching, getting at the French, but they outnumber them, and eventually succumb to their disgust and die. You must retreat, in utter humiliation, and eventually stare down the face of death itself - frogs.

My opinion will assuredly be a divisive one, but I find that the best survival games are games in which dealing with hunger, thirst, etc. are something that is a huge deal, but eventually wanes after you establish a good base of operations and a system, making the gathering of food, water, etc. a very minor task with other activities taking the forefront.   Empyrion Galactic Survival had me picking plants and killing space raptors and cooking the meat to stay alive while on the run, trying to heal myself and get some ore and supplies to build, and once I stayed alive long enough to build a little base, I could make a refrigerator and a little farm with growth lights over it and make my own food. After that, I had to always be wary of my hunger, but it was not the entire goal of the game any more. In Subnautica, getting fish to eat was and fish to produce water from was a big deal. Then you get a few upgrades, find the most filling fish, pack 'em with salt to make them last, find spots with heaps of water-generating fish and machine parts to extract clean water, and you're good to go! You always have to watch the meter and carry some goodies with you, but that is largely behind you now. Even Minecraft, which I didn't really like, allows you to heavily get some production going to handle hunger.  In Don't Starve Together, however, even with a team mate, food acquisition was our entire point of existence for far too long. She would wander off desperately looking for food, I would do the same, and we'd meet back up and eat what we had. It was never enough, despite devoting our entire in-game days to gathering food and just enough wood, etc. to make a fire to survive through the night. On a few other runs, we tried creating technology, but we could not find the components we needed to create stuff that would be of any use. On top of that, I simply did not like the tech options that were listed based on what I read of them.  To me, this game was a complete and utter chore to play. I am not exaggerating when I say that I would rather be at work than playing this game. I am happy that others are able to derive some joy from it, though I absolutely cannot. If keeping your hunger, etc. meters high hits your joy button, then Don't Starve Together will entertain you and your friends. However, if you prefer to have massive quality of life improvements to hunger, etc. throughout your play as a result of your hard work in-game, a la Empyrion: Galactic Survival and Subnautica, then I would urge you to play those games instead.

The game is a fun time waster, but I have played better. As far as survival goes I have also played better. The game keeps throwing challenges at you, or destroying your stuff to make it seem more than it is. I found the fact that this game has many rave reviews bothersome. I cannot find much to like about the game other than art and sound.      The game itself wouldn't be that bad, if it had some kind of story, or reason for you to do these things. What it gives you is a randomly generated world that has limited reasources, which forces you to move on continuously. Leaving behind all the items you have built. For some people this may be fun. As for me I found it as enjoyable as working in an assembly plant. With all the charm too.       I have interacted with the "community" for about a month or so and have found them lacking. I have had to edit my review multiple times to hopefully help to them understand why I don't like this game.       I even tried again to like this game after the "community" bashed on me for writing a negative review. I found myself gazing at the game in a mild hypnosis, grinding away getting resources. I was in a trance for about 2hrs, not because I liked the game, or because I was enjoying myself, but because I was just playing to play.       After that I took the time to re-edit my review and again the "community" pounced and started hating on me for not like their game. Well too bad, I can't find any more redeeming qualities to the game or its "community." I don't feel like being part of a "communtiy" that has to defend its like of a game by tearing those who don't like it down.       I hope this gives the "community" some understanding why I don't like their precious game.

I had my experience with Klei a long time ago. I remember playing Shank 1 and 2 when I was only 13-15 years old. I played them so much I bought them again on this steam account. Now for DST... From my observations, I would not recommend this game to players who have not played Don't Starve beforehand.   The Forge gamemode: It is a gamemode I've enjoyed a lot which is the closest thing this game has to a dungeon. Despite the fact that there is no innate competitiveness, there is a lot of rampant toxicity and elitism in The Forge gamemode. Every game I've played in that mode, there was someone harassing another player based on either their "level" or "wrong actions" in-game. Since there is no mute button or report feature, a lot of these issues fly under the radar and I expect this level of toxicity to remain constant despite the casualness of the game.   Base game: Even though it is a co-op game, a lot of the players harbour a constant fear of strangers leading them to be very hesitant in offering aid. Couple that with the fact that certain players expect others to be a veteran DS player creates a community that is not very helpful or welcoming towards newer players. Admittedly, griefers may appear and burn down your base or newer players may not know what to do and drain your resources. This paranoia permeates throughout the playerbase. Nevertheless, it is a game that requires a lot of personal research on your part despite its casual nature. There is no definite goal to the game, you are simply required to survive for as long as you can. Progression in the game as a whole is based on getting cosmetic items.

Coming from someone who hasn't played this game much, I enjoy it; but I'm not motivated enough to fully experience it.  Don't starve together can be played single player or co-op, The majority of my little hours are co-op and a small amount of time singleplayer.  The game has a cool old fashioned art style and danger around every corner, unlike the first Don't Starve, death is not permanent; but does have a negative effect on future play.   Finding resources is easy, but you need to obtain large quantities for your crafting, which is fairly likited but enough for it to still be enjoyable.  Combat is an option, but isn't viable most of the time. You can craft spears and some swords late game, and basic armour that can help soak up a few more hits; but thats about it. Combat will get you killed.  All the tools die very quickly, even the harder to make ones with gold and other difficult to obtain resources.   Cooking is awesome, but requires lots of different ingredients which are usually painful to obtain. Also, very little dishes replenish health, and if they do it's never very much.  Imo, if I was motivated to play I'd have a blast. It just takes a very long time to get anywhere in your game, and as soon as winter comes if you are not fully prepared you'll get obliterated by the cold, starvation or penguins. Damn penguins.  I'd reccomend to anyone wih enough time to play this game.

I played the original Don't Starve. A fairly simple game that never ceased to amuse me with it's charm and story and features. This game is literally a carbon-copy with a few new items and a brand-new game-defining feature: MULTIPLAYER! Here are some pros and cons about the game:  Pros: * Addictive gameplay * Extensive crafting system * Great playable characters (except for Wolfgang) * Charming graphics and art * Stupid amount of replay value * Multiplayer with friends is ridiculously fun * Multiplayer with randoms is ridiculously fun * Offline mode=Don't Starve * Chester  Cons: * No expansion on story * Tallbirds * No Weber  Honestly, one of my favourite games of all time definitely worth the money. I continue to play the Beta even now and I still enjoy it as much as I did when I got it.  10/10  Would get killed by a mob of Tallbirds again.

At launch the game had many bugs and me and my friends had a hard time playing due to server problems. My friends had bugs like clicking a monster to attack it, instead they start walking towards it. Stuff like that put us off a lot. A couple of months later this game is a blast. We had so much fun without all these bugs. It was amazing to just play all afternoon, build a nice big base, have stored enough food and materials to survive the winter, just so a giant can come, destroy out base and kill us. Twice. On two worlds. Even then it was fun and enjoyable. I recommend this game to and survival game fan as this is one pretty hardcore survival and rogue-like game. If you have 2-3 friends to play with, I suggest playing with them instead of joining a random server, but it's up to you. Can't wait for the game to get out of beta, even though it kinda feels like a complete game as of now.

Theres lot of upvotes and ilove this game too but im gonna focus on the cons for this review, all the pros have already been well gone over. if your looking for fun pvp this game is not ready for it yet, the system makes it near impossible to kill someone if all they do is run away, and when you dstart trading blows it seems mostly luck to see who stun the servers go on for weeks at a time, all materials are gone and its ner impossible to join a game and actually get a foothold. i think this could be fixed by having stuff like grass and beerrry bushes growing back after a time once someone burns them down, which happens alot more then you would think. Also want to go over the lag, you can work for a couple hours gathering stuff to get read for pvp then once you enter any kind of combat start rubber banding, which means your character will appear to be moving then dissapear or walk back to the spot you started lagging out on. its a host problem for the deicated servers so if they could update those it would be alot more playable. imagine getting attacked and trying to run away, with everytime you get some distance between you and your enemy and you think you got away, your character appears right back next to the enemy and half your health is gone, repeat until your frusturated and dead. in conclusion the game needs way more content as its way to easy to reach a point where you built everything and your kinda just waiting to die and start over. the dedicated servers need to be completely redone and the lag on those servers needd to be worked on for lag issues.

It's a very fun game, the art style, game play cater to my wants. If you're new to Don't Starve the game throws into the world and lets you learn and explore the world. The game doesn't hold your hand with tutorials so it may be tough at first if you don't know what you're getting yourself into. This game is alot of fun with friends and still playable when going solo. I find the game to be calm as you build your base and prepare for the seasons and other deadly threats. There is a lot of lore and continuous support from the developers as they release new free events, new characters and different optional customization.  Oh and how could i forget when you buy this game you get second gift copy to gift to one of your friends so you both can Not starve together.

Personally, i'd like to think that don't starve is one of the better survival games out there and i'd definitely recommend it to those who want a game that isn't afraid to throw any punches at you if you are not careful, though there is one of this games more common problem, it may be too hard for its own good. I've watched clueless players get killed constantly and never end up playing the game again. If you (the reader) are wondering whether or not to buy this game, id say go for it, but until klei adds a hinting system for newer players, i'd recommend looking at some tutorials when it comes to surviving the first few days. Trust me, i've been in that newbie spot but once you've got your hands on the ropes, its one hell of a game and time...   But things aren't as great when your alone right?.... Nope, so bring a friend with you, survive the harsh lands and make sure you BOTH Don't Starve Together...

This is less of a bad thing on Klei's part, but more on Steam's. I don't understand. If my friend played more of the game before I purchased it, then why would those hours when he was playing it for free count toward my account? Don't Starve Together is a great game to play with large groups of friends, the worlds are randomly generated and each season brings new challenges to the game. Each base game character has pros and cons that allow them to be balanced yet fun, the combinations of these characters abilities also adds variety to gameplay.  Pros: Fun to play with friends Random worlds add challenge The customisation of characters (Visual and Team Composition is fun) The settings allow even more customisation of the world Mods from the community section add a lot of replay value  Cons: With many players the food can be lacking in some biomes The game can seem too punishing with enemies (Walrus Range etc.)
