Insanely hard. At least in Terraria you could kind of, set yourself up, lock yourself away for the night. This game will constantly kick you when you're down. Need to increase your sanity? Good luck doing that without starving to death. Finally got enough grass for a sleeping bag? It's one use, and now you don't have grass to make a fire. Just started raining? Good luck keeping your fire going while you're attacked by four bats.   Edit: I managed to enjoy this game a little more by adding mods.  Edit 2: I don't really like the combat, kiting is annoying. Edit 3: The visuals are cute and there is depth in the crafting system if you can tolerate the high learning curve to find it. I imagine the game was very different on launch. Addons have cluttered the menus and there are not enough in-game instructions for new players.

The whole game is just meh.  Farming crops/stones/ores/fruit = Holding down the mouse button. Normal pickaxe or golden doesn't seems to matter all that much. So I got a Mod to increase their durability as I doubt chopping down 5 trees would kill an axe.  Combat is the same. It's just a check on who has higher health, defense and attack speed. There is no skill involved in it. If it at least was a bit like Zelda A link to past it could have been far more fun. Build an iron armor or wood armor as quickly as possible btw. But the best way to combat spiders is just by using traps.  Various things are a bit unreasonable. Like food. Why do I need to eat 8-7 steaks to fill up my hunger to max? Do you really eat 7-8 steaks per day? You can eat so many roasted berries without getting full either. It's kinda ridiculous.  Why does the temperature gets to freezing during rain in spring when the normal temperature was 27 celcius? Also why can't I just build a shelter to stay under? Also why does it rain for what seems like 3-4 full days?  Why do I need to use poop for every plant I plant?    Overall it really isn't all that fun. I tried to enjoy it for the 9 hours I played but meh. Not worth it.

I should preface this by saying that my son in law is african american. We routinely play video games together as a sort of bonding experience. One in particular is the 2d powerhouse Terraria. I really wanted to enjoy Don't Starve. I had seen the Totalbiscuit review of this game ((that part where he hunts for manure LOL!!)), and thought the game had looked interesting at the time. However, I had clearly not had paid too decent attention to the review.. when we fired the game up, my laptop, his pc, we began chosing characters. To which poses the question.. Why are there no african american characters? Is it coicidental that the actual only "dark" character happens to be a monster, aka, the spider? It's 2017 now, and in this climate of change, you would think that the indie game scene would be the first to change. I've seen some games take charge in the war against racism and white privelege, but this is a survival game, which strives for REALISM. In an apocalyptic setting, there would be african americans. There would be latinos. There would be muslims, and anyone else.. Not just white people. I saw the available characters and I told him to shut it down. We decided to play l4d2 instead, a survival game with actual minds put behind it. Take some responsibility, you are the face of a generation. You can make the change, if you have an open mind, open heart, and bravery. It's a shame that so many these days do not though.

A good old survival game. This game has a different art-style and actual characters/personalities than the usual survival games. A lot more fun with friends. Each season is different from eachother, meaning different tempatures, different bosses, different enemies and mobs, depending on seasons. There are also caves and ruins that you can explore! And of course, they have lots of different treasures! You can also get in-game drops, which are purely cosmetic and do not give any benefit to the player other than cosmetic reasons. You do not have to spend a dime in game, you can just play normally and gain drops by playing! Which is an another plus. The only nitpick I can give is maybe the community, but it's here and there, it's mostly just russian trolls, which are to be expected from a popular survival game.  8/10 Very Good!

One of my favorite games. Strong mechanics especially survival ones in an industry studded with survival games where survival is more of an annoyance than a strength. Outside of that, the graphics are very stylised and fit the theme and feel of the game, and the devs have taken simple mechanics like kiting and cooking and made them into something really special that most games don't give you. At the time of this review I have 124 hours on the game and each one has been a blast. Honestly before I even go into detail, buy the game if you love not only the art style, but the survival genre in general. This game does have some flaws, such as the occasionally crash or connectivity issues, but for the most part, Klei have made an amazing thing with this. If you're a fan of the original Don't starve and it's gameplay, then you will feel right at home here. However, your home is no longer an issue.  Now your house is full of your friends and even some strangers, how'd they get here, allowing you and the others to either work together or against each other. For the most part the player base is very nice to each other. Of course some people won't be a saint, but very few people will be mad if you're a new player. While playing online, if someone joins my server that is new I teach them the basics and let them discover the game for themselves.  The items in the game are a nice addition of character cosmetics. Now this is not a perfect game and isn't for everyone, but if you are curious about this game, my advice is to try it. This game is something fun to do and meet people on. The survival is refined and keeps the player engaged and planning with its in game seasons. Overall, this game is definitely a 8.5-9/10. This game is the survival game to just hang out and relax on with your friends. The key is to never really worry about "playing the game wrong." Just have fun with exploring and trying everything this game offers.

As far as survival games go this is one of the better ones in my opinion. Unlike Minecraft this game's difficultly very much increases when night falls thus making defense preparation and strategy making a much higher priority. This coupled with the hunger and sanity levels being a core focus of the game and directly effecting gameplay makes it quite an enjoyable experience. I also found the Seasonal Changes to be quite an enjoyable element of the game limiting what resources are available and can be collected at any given time. In addition the multiplayer feature of the game is solid and with the game's lower system requirements it can be played on any modestly powerful IBM Compatible PC. So for those of you who want a fun strategy/survival game you can play with friends I'd say it's worth your time and money.

I got this game because I was trying to find something to play with my gf. She's not a gamer at all, so I needed a more simple game that would be fun for her while also being challenging for me, but that I wouldn't have to just carry her through it.  We just got it recently, but this game has been great for that. It's simple enough with the scavenge and build mechanic that it's pretty easy to understand. I take over more of the combat which can be difficult at times, especially when you both get swarmed. Overall, it's a great game to play together, especially since we're long distance. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone else trying to find something to get their girl into gaming.

[h2] How I played [/h2] I played ~20 hours of Don't Starve (singleplayer) and ~80 hours of Don't Starve Together in groups of 2-3 with about 5 friends.  I have not played the new "Return of Them" update though it looks to have expanded the end game. [h2] The First 20 Hours [/h2] Don't Starve Together begins at its best: as a treacherous adventure.  Building a routine, discovering the behavior of strange creatures, and responding to unseen events slowly increases your confidence that you can beat your previous record.  However, you will likely die due to a lack of preparation every new season.  I believe that this stage of the game holds up for both solo and group players. However, be careful how you build your group.   [b] An experienced player should not introduce a new player to this game [/b].  My attempts to have new friends join result in me warning them of the dangerous surprises that are supposed to be overcome.  It is obviously much more fun mismanaging your base and starving together than having someone tell you how to play. [h2] 20 - 60 Hours [/h2] During this stage, it was important to me that I played with a group.  Routine days, where you could just chat with friends, are punctuated by engaging encounters.  At this stage, the nuances Klei have filled their world up with begin to surface.  Some of these details can be utilized to expand your base and some just make the world feel richer. [h2] 60 Hours & On [/h2] This game has a lot of content and I already got a lot of hours.  However, you know you're not going to die unless you start taking risks at this point.  If you're planning on dominating your world, then there is still a lot of content.  However, I was really only interested in overcoming the survival challenge. [h2] Conclusion [/h2] Don't Starve Together was one of the best games I've played.  I suggest you find at one person who has the same level of experience in the game as you and you'll get more than your money's worth.

This game is very challenging and requires you to learn how to play it to get past certain points, almost like learning a new skill. The art, both music and visual are pretty exceptionally well done and very unique to the game in particular. The developers are also very open about their userbase modding the game so when you go through the workshop you can completely personalize your entire Don't Starve experience. The only complaint I have about this game, (and it's pretty major) is that this game has no idea how to reward you and doesn't know how to keep challenging you once you've learned it. But, trust me, you will not figure this game out in a couple of days unless you've got a surplus of time.

Outside of my personal affinity with Webber, this is probably my favorite multiplayer game of all time, at least in terms of ones for just playing with a few other friends. Even with my multiple obsessive phases over this game, I still find new content almost every time I play it, either from updates or just me finding something for the first time even after over a hundred hours. The potential in this game is vast, from creative projects like base-building, genuinely stressful bosses, to just hours and hours of satisfying progression at a group. It's hard to ever get bored of the game, and the only reason I don't have infinitely more hours on it is I get butthurt sometimes after i mess up a long run.  PLAY IT

DST is one of my favorite survival games. It has a very lovably spooky-cute art style and sound design, a surprising amount of lore, the option to play solo, a whole cast of funky characters, and a whole lot more! It's one of the only games I'll willingly play single-player, and I love to play with friends and strangers alike! I've sunk a lot of hours into this game, and I feel like you might like to as well.  The game is mostly user-friendly and plenty of other players are open to helping out those who are lost! It provides a challenging survival experience without making it too hard to enjoy.   The modding community is very creative and have all sorts of fun little things to add to your game like original characters, new crafting recipes, and anything you could think of to tailor the game to your needs!

A Tim Burton-esque type game that I particularly enjoy and spend hours playing with friends some days when they want to. This game never has a pause feature, I am lucky I can go take a break for a bit while playing this game. I have the tendency to also frequently die, though I am still able to have a great time nonetheless and the daily log-in bonus is a plus as well. It was not a thing originally where a person would just play to earn items, but logging in to receive a daily item is exciting. The fact that Klei is still willing to update the game and provide us with new characters for the game with new skins is also exciting. I own all the recent DLC characters with a majority of their skins which I find aesthetically pleasant to my eyes.

Ooooohhh this is good! I love the way the characters and entities move with the land and sea. The game isn't 2D or 3D, but rather it is somewhere in the middle of the two, which makes DST stand out as unique. Another great aspect is that certain characters have starting items as well as sets of strengths and weaknesses that give them a leg up on other characters. The caves are a mysterious aspect to the game, and when exploring them, there is no telling what could happen. Lastly, the seasons and seasonal events, monsters and animals are a huge plus. There is so much else to say, and these are only a few great aspects. If I were you, I would definitely give this game try!

Don't Starve Together is a very cool game to play with your friends on Twitch or even in private. The whole point is to help each other and survive. That game is very hard when you don't know exactly what to do. I remember my first time playing, my friend said DON'T TOUCH ANYTHING, IT WILL KILL YOU. And she was right, a fricking tree attacked me and i died. There's even a system for skins and clothes you can have. There's also a lot of different characters on the vanilla game that are very cool even tho my favorites are from the workshop. If you wanna play like any others player you'll have to download a few basic mods but this game is still very cool and i really don't mind spending 15€ to play it.

The game is fun. It comes with a good balance in difficulty that allows you to play long enough to discover something new just before you die and have to start over. If you like Roguelike games and don't get too discouraged by dying and starting over, then this game has loads to offer if you keep trying again and keep progressing forward.
